scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded: 'Lisa, I know it's challenging, but we can do it if we support each other and stay focused.' Now, [Monica] and [Bob] are also expressing their concerns. [Monica] looks worried and says, 'I'm afraid we're setting ourselves up for failure.' [Bob] frowns and adds, 'I agree with Monica. This is unrealistic.' You responded: 'I understand it's tough, but maybe we can find a way to make it work if we focus on the most critical tasks first.' [Monica] crosses her arms and [Bob] runs a hand through his hair, both looking tense. You suggested listing out potential risks and seeing how to mitigate them.
scenes.description: [Monica] sighs and [Bob] looks at you, still uncertain about the plan.

options.text: I know it's a lot, but we can handle it if we take it one step at a time.
options.analysis: You acknowledged the challenge and suggested a step-by-step approach, showing good emotional detection and interpersonal balance skills.

options.text: We need to stay positive and focused. Doubting ourselves won't help.
options.analysis: You encouraged a positive attitude and focus, demonstrating good emotional control and communication skills, but emotional detection could be slightly improved.

options.text: Maybe we should reconsider if this project is worth the effort.
options.analysis: You suggested reconsidering the project's worth, showing a balance of emotional detection and social skills, though emotional regulation could be enhanced.
